name: April
title: APRIL WANG
subtitle: Assistant Professor at ETH Zürich, the Department of Computer Science

bio.name: April Yi Wang
bio.announcement: 📣 I am actively looking for enthusiastic undergrads, MS, and PhDs to reimagine the future of programming tools for collaboration and learning. Please check the join us page for more details!
bio.about: I am a tenure-track assistant professor in the Department of Computer Science at ETH Zürich, directing the Programming, Education, and Computer-Human Interaction Lab (PEACH Lab). I am a core faculty member at the Institute for Intelligent Interactive Systems, and associated with the ETH AI Center. I am also part of ETH HCI, Swiss CHI. My main area of research is in human-computer interaction (HCI) and educational technology.
bio.bio: I work on creating collaborative, intelligent, and human-centric programming environments that cater to the evolving educational and professional spheres. I view programming as a tool for instructing computers to aid human tasks, and my research is focused on making programming more accessible beyond traditional code writing. My goal is to enhance the daily work efficiency of the general public by making programming tools user-friendly for a diverse usage cases. Recognizing the importance of computational literacy in our technology-driven world, my research also aims to enhance the effectiveness of teaching innovations in computer science classrooms. To achieve this, I develop tools that make programming classrooms more engaging, scalable, and accessible. My work has been published at top-tier HCI venues (e.g., CHI, TOCHI, CSCW), and has received several paper awards.

featured_project.name: Understanding Challenges in Collaborative Data Science
featured_project.description: Understand the challenges of collaborative data science in various setups, including real-time co-editing, multidisciplinary team communication, and reuse of analysis code.

featured_project.name: Designing Collaborative Tools for Data Science Practitioners
featured_project.description: Design collaborative tools for data science practitioners, including contextual links for explanations, AI-assisted documentation, and visualizing data changes.

featured_project.name: Designing Collaborative Tools for Programming Learners
featured_project.description: Designing collaborative tools for programming learners by making it easier for students to seek instructional help or seek peer help for testing and reviewing code.

item.title: Colaroid: A Literate Programming Approach for Authoring Explorable Multi-Stage Tutorials
item.authors: April Yi Wang, Andrew Head, Ashley Zhang, Steve Oney, and Christopher Brooks
item.venue_full: In Proceedings of the ACM Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI 2023)
item.abstract: Colaroid tutorials are augmented computational notebooks, where snippets and outputs represent a snapshot of a project, with source code differences highlighted, complete source code context for each snippet, and the ability to load and tinker with any stage of the project in a linked IDE.
item.video_teaser: <iframe width='560' height='315' src='https://www.youtube.com/embed/Oy1PRi8vov8' title='YouTube video player' frameborder='0' allow='accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture' allowfullscreen></iframe>

item.title: Strategies for Reuse and Sharing among Data Scientists in Software Teams
item.authors: Will Epperson, April Yi Wang, Robert DeLine, and Steven M. Drucker
item.venue_full: In Proceedings of the ACM/IEEE 44th International Conference on Software Engineering: Software Engineering in Practice (ICSE-SEIP 2022)
item.abstract: Conducted interviews and surveys with data scientists at Microsoft, and extract five commonly used strategies for sharing and reuse of past work: personal analysis reuse, personal utility libraries, team shared analysis code, team shared template notebooks, and team shared libraries.

item.title: Telling Stories from Computational Notebooks: AI-Assisted Presentation Slides Creation for Presenting Data Science Work
item.authors: Chengbo Zheng, Dakuo Wang, April Yi Wang, Xiaojuan Ma
item.venue_full: In Proceedings of the ACM Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI 2022)
item.abstract: Presented NB2Slides, an AI system that facilitates users to compose presentations of their data science work.

item.title: Diff in the Loop: Supporting Data Comparison in Exploratory Data Analysis
item.authors: April Yi Wang, Will Epperson, Robert DeLine, and Steven M. Drucker
item.venue_full: In Proceedings of the ACM Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI 2022)
item.links: PDFPaper Talk
item.abstract: Explored the idea of visualizing differences in datasets as a core feature of exploratory data analysis, a concept we call Diff in the Loop (DITL)
item.video_teaser: <iframe width='560' height='315' src='https://www.youtube.com/embed/BWGJxfy3OY8' title='YouTube video player' frameborder='0' allow='accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture' allowfullscreen></iframe>

item.title: Documentation Matters: Human-Centered AI System to Assist Data Science Code Documentation in Computational Notebooks
item.authors: April Yi Wang*, Dakuo Wang*, Jaimie Drozdal, Michael Muller, Soya Park, Justin D. Weisz, Xuye Liu, Lingfei Wu, and Casey Dugan
item.venue_full: ACM Transactions on Computer-Human Interaction (TOCHI 2021)
item.abstract: Designed Themisto, an automated documentation generation system to explore how human-centered AI systems can support human data scientists in the machine learning code documentation scenario.

item.title: HAConvGNN: Hierarchical Attention Based Convolutional Graph Neural Network for Code Documentation Generation in Jupyter Notebooks.
item.authors: Xuye Liu*, Dakuo Wang*, April Yi Wang, Yufang Hou, and Lingfei Wu
item.venue_full: In Proceedings of the 2021 Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing: Findings (EMNLP 2021)
item.abstract: Proposed a new model (HAConvGNN) that uses a hierarchical attention mechanism to consider the relevant code cells and the relevant code tokens information when generating the documentation.

item.title: PuzzleMe: Leveraging Peer Assessment for In-Class Programming Exercises
item.authors: April Yi Wang*, Yan Chen*, John Joon Young Chung, Christopher Brooks, and Steve Oney
item.venue_full: In Proceedings of the ACM : Human-Computer Interaction, Computer-Supported Cooperative Work and Social Computing (CSCW 2021)
item.abstract: Presented PuzzleMe, a tool to help Computer Science instructors to conduct engaging in-class programming exercises.

item.title: How AI Developers Overcome Communication Challenges in a Multidisciplinary Team: A Case Study
item.authors: David Piorkowski, Soya Park, April Yi Wang, Dakuo Wang, Michael Muller, and Felix Portnoy
item.venue_full: In Proceedings of the ACM : Human-Computer Interaction, Computer-Supported Cooperative Work and Social Computing (CSCW 2021)
item.abstract: Reported on a study including analyses of both interviews with AI developers and artifacts they produced for communication.

item.title: Facilitating Knowledge Sharing from Domain Experts to Data Scientists for Building NLP Models
item.authors: Soya Park, April Yi Wang, Ban Kawas, Q. Vera Liao, David Piorkowski, and Marina Danilevsky
item.venue_full: In Proceedings of the 26th International Conference on Intelligent User Interfaces (IUI 2021)
item.abstract: Proposed Ziva, a framework to guide domain experts in sharing essential domain knowledge to data scientists for building NLP models.

item.title: EdCode: Towards Personalized Support at Scale for Remote Assistance in CS Education
item.authors: Yan Chen, Jaylin Herskovitz, Gabriel Matute, April Wang, Sang Won Lee, and Steve Oney
item.venue_full: In Proceedings of the IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC 2020)
item.abstract: Introduced EdCode, a system that allows students to seek remote instructional support within their IDE in a way that resembles in-person support.

item.title: Callisto: Capturing the Why by Connecting Conversations with Computational Narratives
item.authors: April Yi Wang, Zihan Wu, Christopher Brooks and Steve Oney
item.venue_full: In Proceedings of the ACM Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI 2020)
item.links: PDFPaper Supplemental Material Video Slides
item.abstract: Proposed Callisto, an extension to computational notebooks that captures and stores contextual links between discussion messages and notebook elements with minimal effort from users.

item.title: How Data Scientists Use Computational Notebooks for Real-Time Collaboration
item.authors: April Yi Wang, Anant Mittal, Christopher Brooks and Steve Oney
item.venue_full: In Proceedings of the ACM : Human-Computer Interaction, Computer-Supported Cooperative Work and Social Computing (CSCW 2019).
item.links: PDFPaper Slides
item.abstract: Reported how synchronous editing in computational notebooks changes the way data scientists work together compared to working on individual notebooks.

item.title: Designing Curated Conversation-Driven Explanations for Communicating Complex Technical Concepts
item.authors: April Yi Wang and Parmit K. Chilana
item.venue_full: In Proceedings of the IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing (VL/HCC 2019)
item.links: PDFPaper Slides
item.abstract: Explored a novel approach for explaining technical concepts to non-technical users through the design of JargonLite, an interactive dictionary that shows how technical concepts can be used in everyday conversations.

item.title: Mismatch of Expectations: How Modern Learning Resources Fail Conversational Programmer
item.authors: April Yi Wang, Ryan Mitts, Philip J. Guo and Parmit K. Chilana
item.venue_full: In Proceedings of the ACM Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI 2018)
item.links: PDFPaper Slides
item.abstract: Carried out interviews with 23 conversational programmers to better understand the challenges they face in technical conversations, what resources they choose to learn programming, how they perceive the learning process, and to what extent learning programming actually helps them.

item.title: Social CheatSheet: An Interactive Community-Curated Information Overlay for Web Applications
item.authors: Laton Vermette, Shruti Dembla, April Y. Wang, Joanna McGrenere and Parmit K. Chilana
item.venue_full: In Proceedings of the ACM : Human-Computer Interaction (1,1), Computer-Supported Cooperative Work and Social Computing (CSCW 2018).
item.abstract: Presented Social CheatSheet, an interactive information overlay that can appear atop any existing web application and retrieve relevant step-by-step instructions and tutorials curated by other users.

Officially a Dr.Wang 🎓
I am joining ETH Zürich as an assistant professor in Nov 2023!
I will defend my dissertation at 14:30 EST, August 3.
Honored to receive the Gary M. Olson Award by UMSI.

content.name: April Yi Wang
content.affiliation:
University of Michigan
School of Information

meat.p:
I am a Ph.D. candidate at the School of Information at the University of Michigan, advised by Professor Steve Oney and Professor Christopher Brooks. My research draws upon human-centered design techniques to explore challenges in shared sense-making in data scientists’ collaboration practices and reimagine programming interfaces to support collaboration. I conducted in-depth qualitative inquiries to understand how data scientists currently use computational notebooks for collaboration. I developed computational tools to facilitate shared sense-making in computational notebooks.

I received my B.Eng. in Computer Science from Zhejiang University and M.Sc. degree in Computer Science from Simon Fraser University, where my master thesis investigated non-programmers learning computational literacy.
